columns.text: The problem will require us to define the different terminologies related to EFN and, assuming all debt is constant, show that EFN can be written another way.

## Requirement 1.

Define the following terminologies.

S = Previous year's sales.

A = Total Assets.

E= Total Equity.

g = Projected growth in sales.

PM = Profit margin.

b = retention ratio.

### Define previous year's sales.

Previous Year Sales is the basis to use in calculating the future sales. It is usually the basis for calculating the proportional share of the cost of sales and assets to the sales.

### Define total assets.

Total assets are always directly proportional to the increase in sales. Total assets should be adjusted based on the projected growth. Assets are adjusted as there is a need to check if the assets can support the company's projected growth.

### Define total equity.

Total equity is essential in calculating EFN as we are looking if the company will be able to finance the company's growth.  The equity section is always checked if there is a need for additional equity or if the company has available funds to support the possible expansion.

### Define projected growth in sales.

Projected growth is the possible expansion of the company. The projected growth in sales is needed for the company's proper planning. Projected growth will also be the basis in calculating the EFN of the company.

### Define profit margin.

The profit margin is the measurement of what percentage of revenue is retained after all operating costs. The profit margin should be the same every time we compute the EFN of the company.

### Define retention ratio.

The retention ratio is the percentage of the net income retained to the company as an available fund. The retention ratio is the portion of the retained earnings of the company.

### Provide the formula for calculating EFN.

The formula for calculating EFN is as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned} 
\textbf{EFN}&= \text{(A/S)}  \times \text{(Change in Sales)} - \text{L/S} \times  \text{Change in Sales} - \text{(PM $\times$ FS $\times$ (1-d))}
\end{aligned}
$$

Where: 

**A/S** = Assets that change in a given sales.

**Change in sales** = The difference between forecasted sales and current sales.

**L/S** = Liabilities that change in a given sales.

**PM**: Profit margin on sales.

**FS**: Forecasted sales.

**d**: Dividend payout ratio.

**1-d** = percent of earnings retained after paying out dividends.

Prove that the given formula is the same as the standard formula of EFN.


**1 - D** = equals the retention ratio or letter b of the given formula.

**(A/S) multiplied by the change in sales** = is the same as the -PM(S)b.

**L/S multiplied by the change in sales  less PM multiplied by FS** = is the same as A less PM(S)b
In this task, we are asked to determine certain terms and to prove the given statement.
The **previous year's sales** are total sales from the previous year compared to the current year.

When we talk about a company, the meaning of **total assets** refers to all of the assets or objects of value that the company has. Cash on hand, money owed to you in the form of accounts receivable, inventory, equipment, and other tools are all considered part of a company's overall assets.

Equity is the worth of the company remaining after all obligations have been satisfied. The **total equity** of a company may be calculated by deducting the value of all of its obligations from the value of all of its assets. This leaves a company with its net worth. On the balance sheet of a corporation, equity is shown as an asset.

A **sales projection** is the estimated amount of money that a business anticipates it will make at some time in the future. A sales forecast is an example of this kind of prediction. Both assist assess if an organization is healthy or not, as well as whether sales will increase or decrease.

The company's **profit margin** is the company's profit ratio divided by its revenue. Using the profit margin ratio, you can see how effectively the firm is managing its finances overall by comparing profit to sales. It is usually presented in the form of a percentage.
The **retention ratio** is a measure of how much money a company retains after paying out dividends to shareholders. Investors use it to determine a company's capacity to pay dividends.

EFN (External Finance Needed ) is the difference between what a company can raise from its own earnings and savings and the entire amount of capital necessary to accomplish the planned project or transaction. This overview of external finance is obtained from pro forma financial statements that forecast the financial situation of the firm, such as a pro forma income statement and balance sheet, as well as other financial documents.

External Financing Needed is the difference between the increase in assets and the addition to retained earnings. So formula for calculating EFN is shown below as follows:

$$\text{EFN}=\text{IA}-\text{ARE}$$

Where:

IA = Increase in Assets

ARE = Addition to Retained Earnings

The increase in assets is the result of the beginning assets multiplied by the rate of growth. The formula for calculating increase in assets is shown below:

$$\text{IA}=\text{A}\cdot\text{g}$$

Where:

IA =  Increase in Assets

A = Beginning Assets

g = Growth Rate

The addition to the retained earnings is calculated as the product of present net income and the retention ratio, and the one plus growth rate in the following way:

$$\text{ARE}=(\text{NI}\cdot\text{b})(1+\text{g})$$

Where:

ARE = Addition to Retained Earnings

NI = Net Income

The profit margin is calculated by dividing net income by sales as shown as follows:

$$\text{PM}=\dfrac{\text{NI}}{\text{S}}$$

Where:

PM = Profit Margin

NI = Net Income

S = Sales

Based on the formula for calculating the profit margin, we can express net income in the following way:

$$\text{NI}=\text{PS}(\text{S})$$

Now we will substitute the equations from steps 10, 11, and 13 in the original formula from step 9 and determine the EFN in the following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{EFN}&=\text{IA}-\text{ARE}\\[10pt]
&=\text{A}\cdot\text{g}-\text{PM(S)}\cdot\text{b}\cdot(1+\text{g})\\[10pt]
&=\text{A}(\text{g})-\text{PM(S)}\text{b}-[\text{PM(S)}\text{b}]\text{g}\\[10pt]
&=-\text{PM(S)}\text{b}+[\text{A}-\text{PM(S)\text{b}}]\text{g}
\end{align*}$$

In conclusion, the EFN equation is presented and proven.
